data.text:
Unit 3: Land-Based Empires

C. 1450 - 1750

Topic 3 Empires Expand

Learning Objective

Explain how and why various land-based empires developed and expanded from 1450 to 1750.

Historical Developments

Imperial expansion relied on the increased use of gunpowder, cannons, and armed trade to establish large empires in both hemispheres.

Land empires included the Manchu in Central and East Asia; the Mughal in South and Central Asia; the Ottoman in Southern Europe, the Middle East, and North Africa; and the Safavids in the Middle East.

Political and religious disputes led to rivalries and conflict between states.

State rivalries: ● Safavid3Mughal conflict ● Songhai Empire’s conflict with Morocco

1. Explain how the land-based empires of the 1450-1750 time period

developed (what allowed them to obtain and maintain power):

The land-based empires of the 1450-1750 time period developed by them

conquering lands in other countries and making palaces that reflects their

power. They also made their own people to live with them so they cannot work

against them.

2. Describe the Qing Dynasty (use SPICE-T characteristics):

S- possess pyramid emperor, gentry, agriculturalist, landlords, and peasants.

P- They often like ocean trade, Indian ocean trade.

I- Indian ocean spreads across their land and reduces the expansion of China.

C- There was religious tolerance, indian ocean trade.

E- They are the gunpowder empire.

T-Has gunpowder weapons in the empire.

3. Describe the Mughal Empire (use SPICE-T characteristics):

S-They have a pyramid of different levels and also have rich, middle class and

poor people.

P-They are known to have religious reform.

I- They conquered lands.

C- Islamic religion as well as few christians.

E- Fragmentation.

T-They have gunpowder weapons.

4. Describe the Ottoman Empire (use SPICE-T characteristics):

S- There were mixed marriages peasants paying most taxes.

P-They also had tax collectors, sultans, and also Janissaries.

I- They conquered Constantinople.

C- They were also peasant revolts.

E- They are also the gunpowder empire.

T- They also had gunpowder weapons.

5. Describe the Safavid Empire (use SPICE-T characteristics)

S- They are very religious.

P-They expand empires and reorganize military.

I- They engaged in costly wars.

C- They also spent a lot of time in prayers.

E- Known to have costly wars, bad leadership and possess gunpowder.

T- They have gunpowder weapons

Topic 3 Empires: Administration

Learning Objective

Explain how rulers used a variety of methods to legitimize and consolidate their power in land-based empires from 1450 to 1750.

Historical Developments

Recruitment and use of bureaucratic elites , as well as the development of military professionals, became more common among rulers who wanted to maintain centralized control over their populations and resources

Bureaucratic elites or military professionals: ● Ottoman devshirme ● Salaried samurai

Rulers continued to use religious ideas, art, and monumental architecture to legitimize their rule.

Religious ideas: ● Mexica practice of human sacrifice ● European notions of divine right ● Songhai promotion of Islam

Art and monumental architecture: ● Qing imperial portraits ● Incan sun temple of Cuzco ● Mughal mausolea and mosques ● European palaces, such as Versailles

Rulers used tribute collection , tax farming , and innovative tax-collection systems to generate revenue in order to forward state power and expansion.

Tax-collection systems: ● Mughal zamindar tax

6. Describe how land-based empires utilized military professionals to

maintain power:

The Ottoman Sultans employed a system known as Devshirme, which was essentially

a system in which they abducted enslaved individuals from the tribute nations of their

empire and, once obtained, forced them to serve in the military or make them

administrators of the Empire. Muslims abducted slaves from the Christian inhabitants

of Southern Europe and the Balkans, generally from the ages of 8 to 20, because they

were unable to enslave Muslims. They had advanced schooling. The enslaved youths

who made up the Janissaries were groomed to be an elite unit in the Ottoman army,

and they developed a strong loyalty to the Sultan.

7. Explain how land-based empires utilized religious art and ideas to

maintain power:

Land-based empires included theological concepts like the doctrine of the divine

right of kings, as was the case in England under King James I. James firmly believed

that the reason kings governed was because god himself had placed them in that

position. This was a wise move because if the populace and the monarch accepted

the doctrine of the Divine Rights of Kings, they would be challenging the existence of

God, which was something that no Christian wanted to undertake. These theological

concepts were shown in works of art where monarchs in thrones are given the

authority of kingship by a hand from above the sky, which is thought to be God.

8. Explain how land-based empires utilized monumental architecture to

maintain power:

The Palace of Versailles was constructed by Louis the 13th as a means of hiding his

tyranny. Once this palace was finished, Louis issued a proclamation mandating that

the French Nobles move there and made it exceedingly difficult for them to disagree.

In Japan, Tokugawa Ieyasu followed Louis the 13th's example and mandated that the

daimyo maintain two residences4one in their home territory and the other in Tokyo,

A disagreement about who should succeed the current Islamic leader was the cause

of the division. Sunnis thought Abu Bakr, the prophet's close friend, should be the new

successor, while Shi'a thought Ali, the prophet's son-in-law, should.

14. Why did this split intensify during the 1450-1750 time period?

Political rivalries between the Ottoman and Safavid empires intensify the split between

Sunni and Shi'a.

15. Explain how Sikhism developed in relation to the Mughal Empire.

In India, the Mughal Empire rose to power, and the Mughals had a significant

influence on the growth of Sikhism. Emperor Akbar tolerated the Sikhs in 1567. They

were viewed as a danger by a Mughal emperor, which led the Sikhs to militarize in

order to defend their religion.

Land-Based Empires of 1450-

Image via Freemanpedia.

Unit 3: Land-Based Empires (1450-1750) Context Practice

Instructions: Write a contextual statement for each of the prompts below. This will not only help you review content from Unit 3

(1450-1750), but also help you practice writing context statements which, if done successfully, can earn you one point on both the

DBQ and LEQ essays.
